args: I don't care if you are a prince or Ilia\nherself—when I hire someone for a job,\nI expect to see it done.
I'm truly sorry we couldn't recover\nyour daughter.
I don't need apologies, I need results. \nYou'll be certain to capture the girl this\ntime, I should think?
There's something odd about that man.\nHe speaks of recovering his daughter like\nshe's just a missing oil painting.
I'm pickin' up what you're puttin' down,\nboss. This Radelle cat is more sketchy\nthan a first-year art student's notebook!
Still, that phantom thief is as tricksy as\nthey come. Can't rule out the possibility\nshe's foolin' the kid somehow.
We're clearly still in the dark about a lot\nof this, but I don't think we got a choice\nbut to chase after the Blue Rose.
Lapis is a criminal, no doubt,\nbut I'm not certain she's a villain.
...Hmm? You want to know why I continue\nthe work of the Blue Rose?
You just seem like a good person, Lapis.\nI don't understand why you steal.
The acceptable face of justice is not\nenough to save everyone in this world.
So long as there are those who can bend\njustice to their will with power and money,\npeople will be lost in the shuffle.
I thought there was nothing to be done...\nuntil I met...that person.
You see, my parents once ran a\nblack-market auction...

You there! That ring you're selling was my
daughter's engagement ring! She was so
heartbroken when it was stolen that it cost
her her life!

The provenance of this merchandise is not
our concern. If you wish to place the ring
on your daughter's grave, I suggest you 
arrange sufficient funds to bid.
A heart is not a luxury one can afford in\nthis line of work. ...Get him out of here.
Still up, are we? But tomorrow is your\ntea party at Count Derci's residence.
We need you making those connections\nin high society to draw in more clients,\nyou know. ...Stuart! Get in here!
Of course, ma'am. ...Come, I'll escort you\nback to bed.
Can I have some cocoa, Stuart?
But of course, miss. Er, and I hope it's\nnot too forward of me to ask, but...
What were you thinking about when you\noverheard all of that just now?
I was thinking about how awful these\nauctions are. Everything we sell is stolen!
The bidders get the thrill of indulging their\nguilty pleasures and driving up prices,\nwhile the real victims lose out twice.
Do you wish to put an end to your \nparents' business, miss?
I once hoped they might have a change\nof heart, but I know that's a fool's dream.
But many of the auctions' attendees are \npowerful people, and when I tried to go\npublic with it...

I suppose in this world there are some
things you can't change, no matter how
unfair or unforgivable. You just have to
stand by and watch it all happen.
Here's your hot cocoa, miss.\nPerhaps it will make you feel better.
This cocoa has a gentle taste.\nThe Stuart I know could never make cocoa\nlike this.
So I ask again: Who are you, and why\nare you pretending to be Stuart?
Très bien, miss. Tripped up by my own \ncommitment to delicious cocoa.
You know what? I'm feeling good—and\nyou complimented my cocoa besides—\nso I'll let you in on the secret...
Apologies for the ruse, mademoiselle.\nI am the flower that blooms in twilight!\nThe phantom thief! The Blue Rose!
Yes, but my aim is not to simply fill my\npockets like a common criminal. Instead,\nI seek to restore happiness to the world.

All treasure should be returned to its 
rightful place—which means all the stolen
goods in this mansion belong back with
their original owners.
My parents will not like that.
Oui, but of course—which is why I shall\nswap them out with fakes. I work with a\nrather skilled forger, you see.
But so long as the auctions continue,\nthere will be ever more victims.

Indeed, which is why my ultimate prey
is the criminal enterprise that runs the
black market through all South Grastaea.
I speak, of course, of ＂Noir Magazin.＂
The auctions run by your parents are but a\npart of that enterprise. Once it is crushed,\nthe cycle of tragedy can finally end.
Stealing, forging, crushing vast criminal\nenterprises makes for a rather busy life.\nCan you really do all of this?
A foolish question, mademoiselle.\nWhy, a person can soar through the sky\nif they but put their mind to it!

No need to debate. It's a beautiful starry
night, yes? Why don't we both fly out the
window and treat ourselves to a late-night
rendezvous?
(The wind on my face... I AM flying!)
Let's drop on to that church roof\nfor a bit of respite, mmm?
Well, mademoiselle? What did you think\nof our little rendezvous?
We were just pulled along on a wire,\nweren't we?
If you want to get technical, yes—\nbut I still think it counts as flying.

If you say something is impossible,
I respond that you've given up too easily.
Simply change your perspective, and you'll
see there's always a way forward.

You can make the impossible possible.
I keep going because I believe in myself,
no matter how fearsome the foe that might
stand astride my path.
Well then, I'll leave you here to enjoy\nthe church and get back to business.
I'm still not convinced you'll be able\nto save the entire world.
Well, that simply won't do.\nHowever can I convince you?
Steal me away from here. Let me have\na firsthand look at you bringing this\nhappiness to the world.
Never been asked to steal a person before,\nbut très bien...
Oui oui, mademoiselle. I shall steal you\naway like the beautiful rose you are!
From that point on, I helped with the work.\nWe returned stolen treasures and strove\nto bring down the criminal enterprise.
But you're the Blue Rose now.\nSo what happened to the first one?
Eventually, the first Blue Rose took one\nof them over a cliff and into the sea.\nHe hasn't been seen since.
That is why I decided to take up the name.
I help those who've been stolen from,\nand work tirelessly to take down my\nnemesis, Noir Magazin.
So if you succeed, will you stop being\nthe phantom thief?
Oui—but only once there's no one more\ndangerous than me left in the world.
Come, we've rested long enough.\nThe ruins aren't far now.
